bioghist.p: Edwin Wolf 2nd (1911-1991) was a librarian, bibliophile, author, historian, Franklin scholar, and civic leader. He was the Curator of the Library Company of Philadelphia from 1953 to 1955, and its Librarian from 1955 to 1984. Wolf graduated from the William Penn Charter School and then studied at the Bedales School in England. Wolf's father was a founding partner of a prominent Philadelphia law firm, and was friends with Abraham Simon Wolf Rosenbach (d. 1952). Upon his return from England, Edwin Wolf went to work for Dr. Rosenbach. Wolf served in the army during the second World War. After Dr. Rosenbach's death in 1952, Wolf joined the Library Company as a consultant and advisor. Wolf's publications include A History of the Jews of Philadelphia from Colonial Times to the Age of Jackson, Rosenbach: A Biography, and The Library of James Logan of Philadelphia, 1674-1751. He was a member of the American Philosophical Society, and received the Philadelphia Award in 1982 for his decades of service to the city.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the personal and professional papers of Edwin Wolf. Wolf's professional papers include: correspondence and notes on his Library Company projects, his personal scholarship, and his professional affiliations; typescripts, some annotated, of his talks and publications, including the Lyell Lectures in Bibliography; and reprints, off-prints, and published copies of his writings. Notable materials include correspondence, inventories, and notes from the 1960s and 1970s related to the disbursal and whereabouts of Franklin's library; correspondence, notes, and photographs related to the publication of Wolf's books From Gothic Windows to Peacocks and Legacies of Genius; and a scrapbook of clippings from the Jewish Exponent, in which the History of Jews in Philadelphia was serialized. Wolf's personal papers include: school records and correspondence from his time at the Bedales School in England; correspondence between Wolf and his family and wife, Margaret, during his World War II army service; military records; newspaper clippings (1940s); notes for an autobiographical sketch; family photographs, including some late 19th and early 20th century cabinet cards; certificates, awards, and diplomas; a series of artistic photographic prints; and some volumes owned by Wolf, including a family bible.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
